factoid: The Count repeated the phrase "To search far."
Simon was sorry.
The Count said "To search far" while turning back the skirt of his coat to get at his snuffbox.
The Count looked into the distance straight before him, down the narrow open space.
The Count held the snuffbox in his hand but did not take it.
Simon mentioned Michael Sidórych when he came out from Mass in full uniform.
Simon did not finish his sentence.
Simon caught the music of the hunt with only two or three hounds giving tongue.
Simon bent his head down and listened.
Simon shook a warning finger at his master.
Simon whispered that the hounds were on the scent of the cubs straight to the Lyádov uplands.
After the cry of the hounds, deep tones of the wolf call came from Daniel’s hunting horn.
The pack joined the first three hounds and could be heard in full cry, with a peculiar lift indicating they were after a wolf.
The whippers-in changed to the cry of ulyulyu.
Daniel’s voice rose, sometimes deep bass, sometimes piercingly shrill.
Daniel’s voice seemed to fill the whole wood and carried far into the open field.
The Count and his attendant listened in silence for a few moments.
The Count and his attendant convinced themselves that the hounds had separated into two packs.
The larger pack’s sound began to die away in the distance.
The other pack rushed by the wood past the Count.
Daniel’s voice was heard calling ulyulyu as the packs moved.
The sounds of both packs mingled and broke apart again.
Both packs became more distant.
Simon sighed.
Simon stooped to straighten the leash of a young borzoi that had been entangled.
The Count sighed.
The Count noticed the snuffbox in his hand.
The Count opened the snuffbox and took a pinch.
Simon cried "Back!" to a borzoi that was pushing forward out of the wood.
The Count started and dropped the snuffbox.
Nastásya Ivánovna dismounted to pick up the snuffbox.
The Count and Simon were looking at Nastásya.
The sound of the hunt suddenly approached.
The hounds were in full cry and Daniel was ulyulyuing.
The Count turned and saw on his right Mítka staring at him.
Mítka had eyes staring out of his head, raised his cap, and pointed to the other side.
Mítka shouted "Look out!".
Mítka let the borzois slip and galloped toward the Count.
The Count and Simon galloped out of the wood.
They saw on their left a wolf that was softly swaying from side to side.
The wolf was coming at a quiet lope farther to the left to the very place where they were standing.
The angry borzois whined.
The borzois got free of the leash and rushed past the horses' feet at the wolf.
The wolf paused.
The wolf turned its heavy forehead toward the dogs awkwardly.
The wolf was still slightly swaying from side to side.
The wolf gave a couple of leaps.
The wolf swished its tail and disappeared into the skirt of the wood.
At the same instant, first one hound then another then another sprang from the wood opposite.
The whole pack rushed across the field toward the spot where the wolf had disappeared.
Hazel bushes part behind the hounds.
Daniel’s chestnut horse appeared, dark with sweat.
Daniel sat on the long back of the horse.
Daniel was hunched forward, capless.
Daniel had disheveled gray hair hanging over his flushed, perspiring face.
Daniel cried "Ulyulyulyu! ulyulyu!...".
When Daniel saw the Count, his eyes flashed lightning.
Daniel shouted "Blast you!".
Daniel held up his whip threateningly at the Count.
Daniel said "You've let the wolf go!... What sportsmen!".
Daniel lashed the heaving flanks of his sweating chestnut gelding with all the anger the Count had aroused.
Daniel flew off after the hounds.
The Count looked round, trying by a smile to win Simon’s sympathy for his plight.
Simon was no longer there.
Simon was galloping round by the bushes while the field was coming up on both sides.
All were trying to head the wolf.
The wolf vanished into the wood before they could do so.
